thread.title: OHS, Beau Chene fight for first district win
thread.title_full: OHS, Beau Chene fight for first district win

title: OHS, Beau Chene fight for first district win
text:
OHS, Beau Chene fight for first district win Bobby Ardoin 3:50 p.m. CDT October 22, 2015 (Photo: Freddie Herpin/Daily World) 
For one team there’s a postseason vision that hasn’t occurred since 2007. 
The other has different business to consider, like extinguishing a 16-game losing streak dating back to last season. 
It’s also a geographical rivalry both programs annually anticipate and it kicks off again on Friday when Opelousas High and Beau Chene meet at Donald Gardner Stadium beginning at 7 p.m. 
Although it’s a District 4-4A contest, there are no championship implications to consider. 
Instead Opelousas High (0-7, 0-2) and Beau Chene (4-3, 0-2) are both fighting to remain out of the last-place clutches of the league standings. 
Beau Chene hasn’t scored yet in its two 4-4A games. Opelousas has scored once, in its 69-8 district loss to Carencro. 
Josh Guidry, a former Opelousas assistant and now the head football coach at Beau Chene, said the game is important for reasons other than bragging rights. 
“For us, it’s a must win. If we win, we’re in the playoffs. We’ve played probably the best (in 4-4A) already and now we are focused in getting into the playoffs,” Guidry said. 
Guidry said his scrutiny of the Opelousas High situation indicates an opponent that is trying to find solutions. 
“They have some athletes; it looks like they are just trying to put it together within a new system,” said Guidry. 
The Tigers in their first season under head coach Dwight Collins, are playing primarily sophomores and freshmen on both sides of the ball. 
Collins said his team has had some positive moments. Then come the mistakes and bad decisions that have plagued Opelousas all year. 
Both teams have had quarterback difficulties. 
Opelousas has lost quarterback Hunter LaCroix indefinitely due to a knee issue. The Gators have been shuffling their healthy quarterbacks back and forth all year. 
Beau Chene has used Deontrae Eaglin and the reliable Savion Broussard at quarterback. That leaves a backfield of Charles Williams, Markaylin Milburn and Jylon Henry. 
Opelousas will have freshman Shaun Charles at quarterback if LaCroix isn’t in the lineup. Other potential offensive threats for the Tigers include George Dominick. 
Defensively Guidry likes Opelousas linebacker Marlon Young. 
“Opelousas High has enough talent to have us worried.,” Guidry said. 
The Gators won’t throw much, according to Guidry. Beau Chene’s Flex Bone offense likes to keep the ball on the ground and the Gators rarely pass. 
Opelousas has also kept close to the ground. The Tigers’ have had trouble putting offensive drives together and have scored 35 points, an average of less than a touchdown per game. 
Recent Series History 
2014: Beau Chene 23, Opelousas 6 
2013: Beau Chene 12, Opelousas 8 
2012: Opelousas 29, Beau Chene 0 
2011: Beau Chene 39, Opelousas 15 
2010: Beau Chene 7, Opelousas 0 
2009: Opelousas 23, Beau Chene 12 Read or Share this story: http://www.dailyworld.com/story/sports/high-school/2015/10/22/ohs-beau-chene-fight-first-district-win/74414244/ TOP VIDEOS
